title: Irvine Open Space
name: Irvine Open Space
description:
A Map by Baostar

Irvine Ranch reserve areas of more than 50,000 acres of permanently protected open space in the heart of Orange County, California. The reserve land stretches 22 miles from the mountains to the sea and offers rich recreational opportunities, from hiking and horseback riding to bird-watching and picnicking.

properties.name: Anaheim Wilderness Area
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  Marked by deep canyons and steep hillsides, Gypsum Canyon offer docent-led hikes scheduled and conducted by The Nature Conservancy. Reservations for docent-led outings are required due to the area\'s sensitive habitat. As part of a comprehensive environmental assessment, The Nature Conservancy, in partnership with The Irvine Company, will study the area to determine expanded access opportunities in the future. For schedules and reservations, call The Nature Conservancy, (714) 832-7478.

properties.name: Bommer Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  1 Bommer Canyon Road, Irvine, CA 92603Rich in both Irvine Ranch lore and nature\'s bounty, Bommer Canyon beckons walkers and hikers to stroll past centuries-old oak and sycamore groves and craggy rock outcroppings. Reservations are required for outings in Bommer Canyon. A variety of activities are offered by the City of Irvine. For information on activities and schedules, call the city at (949) 724-6835 or visit the City of Irvine Open Space Web site at - http://www.IrvineOpenSpace.org.

properties.name: Crystal Cove State Park
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  Crystal Cove State Park offers 3.5 miles of coastline in its natural state. You can explore tidepools and sandy coves or stroll the length of the beach. The offshore waters are designated as an underwater park with excellent conditions for scuba and skin divers. The beach is popular with swimmers and surfers. Visitors can explore tidepools and sandy coves or stroll the length of the beach.

properties.name: Fremont Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar   Fremont Canyon, Irvine, CADescribed by some as the "the Yosemite of Orange County," Fremont is rich in diversity and history lore. The Nature Conservancy natural conducts docent-led hikes , mountain bike rides and equestrian rides enabling nature-lovers to acquaint themselves with the canyon\'s wonders. Reservations for docent-led outing are required due to the area\'s sensitive habitat. As part of a comprehensive environmental assessment, The Nature Conservancy, in partnership with The Irvine Company, will study the area to determine expanded access opportunities in the future.

properties.name: Irvine Lake
properties.description: Posted by Baostar 4621 Santiago Canyon Road, Silverado, CANestled at the base of the Cleveland National Forest, the 700-acres lake offers a wide menu of outdoor activities, from fishing for trout, bluegill and catfish, to pleasure boating, youth overnight camps, birthday parties, and family reunions. Privately operated. For more information, call the lake office, (714) 649-9111.

properties.name: Irvine Regional Park
properties.description: Posted by Baostar   1 Irvine Park Road, Orange, CA 92862Irvine Regional Park is nestled among a grove of heritage Oak and Sycamore trees. The rolling foothills surrounding the park are filled with a variety of wildlife. Trees, shaded turf areas provide a serene setting for leisure activities. Santiago Creek bisects the park and a pond with stone-work waterfall and foot bridge is located in the center of the park. The variety of landscape greatly enhances the park\'s beauty. Operated by the County of Orange Harbors, Beaches & Parks. For more information, call the park, (714) 633-8074.

properties.name: Jeffrey Open Space Trail
properties.description: Posted by Baostar   10601 Jeffrey Rd, Irvine, CA 92602Bordering the east side of Jeffrey Road, the Jeffrey Open Space Trail is a recreation and open space corridor park that will span Irvine\'s entire north-south length. This rare community amenity will make it possible for residents (if they\'re so inclined and can muster the stamina) to bicycle, jog or walk, literally, from one end of the city to the other. As envisioned in concept, the trail will ultimately link up with trails leading deep into the vast preserved wildlands north and south of the city. Thus, a unique sage to sea outdoor experience will emerge. The trail will feature a dual trail system: an 11-foot-wide paved trail for bicyclists, and a parallel five-foot-wide unpaved path for joggers and walkers. At numerous points, the trail will pass through cool wooded areas and open to small and large parks and grassy meadows. At these picturesque junctures, residents will be able to enjoy picnics, kite flying and other passive recreational activities.

properties.name: Laguna Coast Wilderness Park
properties.description: Posted by Baostar    20101 Laguna Canyon Road, Laguna Beach, CA 92651 From wind-buffeted bluffs to challenging trails, Laguna Coast Wilderness Park offers a rich recreational menu for walker, hikers, mountain-bikers and equestrians. A variety of guided activities are offered at the park by Laguna Greenbelt, Inc., The Nature Conservancy, The City of Irvine and The Irvine Ranch Land Reserve Trust. The park is open every Saturday and Sunday from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m for independent hiking, mountain bike and equestrian users on specified trails. Reservations are required for the docent-led tours. Operated by the County of Orange Harbors, Beaches & Parks. For more information and schedules, call the park, (949) 923-2235. To make a reservation for a guided tour call The Nature Conservancy (714) 832-7478 or the park at (949)923-2235.

properties.name: Limestone Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar   Beautiful geological formations — including an unusual formation called "the Sinks" — plus a rich diversity of flora and fauna make the canyon a favorite among hikers, mountain bikers and naturalists. Access is limited; reservations for docent-led outings are required due to the area\'s sensitive habitat. For schedules and reservations, call The Nature Conservancy, (714) 832-7478.

properties.name: Mason Regional Park
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  18712 University Dr., Irvine, CA 92612At 345 acres, one of Orange County\'s most popular regional parks…a wonderful blend of nature and recreational opportunities, including walking paths, picnic area and a Frisbee course. Operated by the County of Orange Harbors, Beaches & Parks. For more information, call the park, (949) 854-2491.

properties.name: Peters Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar   Riparian and freshwater marshes, abundant wildlife, beautiful vistas — and hiking, walking and biking trails from which to appreciate it all — make Peters Canyon a popular Orange County outdoor destination. Operated by the County of Orange Harbors, Beaches & Parks. For more information, call the park, (714) 227-1780.

properties.name: Round Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  Another area newly opened for docent-led outings, features vibrant tree and plant communities that make the canyon ideal for large populations of animals, especially birds. A family-friendly 3.6-mile roundtrip hike offers pleasant views of the canyon and its habitats. In nearby Agua Chinon, a fairly strenuous five-mile roundtrip hike takes participants to “the Sinks,” a beautiful formation in Limestone Canyon. Reservations are needed for outings.

properties.name: San Joaquin Wildlife Sanctuary
properties.description: Posted by Baostar Riparian View, Irvine, CAOnce a degraded marshland, now one of the largest coastal freshwater marshlands in Southern California. Ten miles of trails popular with walkers, joggers, bird-watchers and families out for a scenic, leisurely stroll. Owned by Irvine Ranch Water District and managed by the San Joaquin Wildlife Sanctuary. For information on wildlife education programs and tours, call the Sea & Sage Audubon Society. Area map:

properties.name: Santiago Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  Santiago Canyon embodies the romance and lore of Orange County\'s colorful history: The canyon\'s past is punctuated by coal-mining operations, grizzly bear hunts, manhunts and homesteaders. The canyon was a major thoroughfare for early settlers who settled in its scenic side canyons—Baker, Black Star, Silverado and Modjeska. Traces of Orange County\'s earliest residents were discovered at nearby Black Star Canyon. Arrowheads and rocks pockmarked with grinder holes—signs that the Indians ground acorns to produce an edible gruel—have been found on the plateau high above the canyon, where a large Indian village once existed. Black Star Canyon got its name in the 1870s, when Black Star Mining Company began mining for coal that recently had been discovered there. The mining operation was short-lived, though, because the quality of the coal was so poor. Santiago Creek flows into Irvine Lake, which was formed in 1931 when a dam was built across lower Santiago Canyon.

properties.name: Upper Newport Bay
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  2301 University Dr., Newport Beach, CA 92660A beautiful setting that offers outstanding outdoor activities: Bird-watching, jogging, bicycling, hiking, kayaking and horseback riding. Home to the Peter and Mary Muth Interpretive Center, which features exhibits and interactive displays that illustrate why Upper Newport Bay is such an important estuary. Operated by the County of Orange Harbors, Beaches & Parks. For more information, call (714) 973-6820.

properties.name: Weir Canyon
properties.description: Posted by Baostar  Marked by deep canyons and steep hillsides, Weir Canyon offers docent-led hikes, equestrian and mountain bike rides scheduled and conducted by The Nature Conservancy. Reservations for docent-led outings are required due to the area\'s sensitive habitat. As part of a comprehensive environmental assessment, The Nature Conservancy, in partnership with The Irvine Company, will study the area to determine expanded access opportunities in the future. For schedules and reservations, call The Nature Conservancy, (714) 832-7478.
